Inimitable

Powered by Punchline

items.title: Tuesday
items.content_text:
Tripitaka: How many coins do you have again?
Mandelbrot: Twelve.
Mandelbrot: You know, that's strange. After all we've been through, and I still haven't
spent any money.
Tripitaka: Well that's good, because I still haven't figured this out.
Tripitaka: Now then, shall I take one, two or three coins?
Tripitaka picks up a coin and taps it against his teeth.
Mandelbrot collects three coins from the pile.
Tripitaka takes two coins and strikes them together.
Mandelbrot also picks up two coins.
Tripitaka takes three coins and slaps his thigh.
Mandelbrot takes a coin from the pile.
Tripitaka hesitates a while.
Mandelbrot: Look, if you can't make a proper analysis of the situation, why don't you
pick at random?
Mandelbrot: Just let me know.
One, Two or Three?
Tripitaka drums his fingers again. He takes one coin.
Mandelbrot: I wish you wouldn't keep tapping all the time.
Mandelbrot takes three coins.
Tripitaka flubs his cheeks a couple of times.
He picks up two coins.
Mandelbrot: Isn't there anything you can do silently?
Tripitaka: Of course. I am a Taoist monk you know.
Mandelbrot: Well you could have fooled me.
Tripitaka: Exactly.
Mandelbrot reaches down and takes another two.
Tripitaka lets out an enormous sneeze.
He seems very pleased with himself, and takes three coins.
Mandelbrot: Honestly. Do you have to make such a noise about everything?
Mandelbrot takes a coin from the pile.
Mandelbrot: Come on, let's just get this over with.
Tripitaka savours the moment. He can pick up
one, two or three coins.
Mandelbrot: Three. Another win to meeeee.
Mandelbrot: Two. And victory.
Mandelbrot: Again.
Mandelbrot: And this one is mine.
Mandelbrot: I win.
items.content_html:
Tuesday

  • Tripitaka

    How many coins do you have again?

  • Mandelbrot

    Twelve.

  • Mandelbrot

    You know, that's strange. After all we've been through, and I still haven't spent any money.

  • Tripitaka

    Well that's good, because I still haven't figured this out.

  • Tripitaka

    Now then, shall I take one , two or three coins?

items.title: Thursday
items.content_text:
Mandelbrot: What kind of sicko wants to play Nim every day, when they know they're going to lose?
Tripitaka: I guess I prefer my freedom of choice.
Mandelbrot: We both have freedom of choice.
Tripitaka: No, I can choose whichever coins I like.
Tripitaka: You on the other hand, are compelled to follow the pattern.
Tripitaka: At the moment I suggest a game, you imagine yourself the winner.
Tripitaka: And consequently, every move you make is decided by me.
Mandelbrot: Well you're forgetting one thing. I own twelve silver coins.
Precisely because I am always the winner.
Tripitaka: And yet you never spend them on anything. You've had them for years.
Tripitaka: It seems all you can do with them is play Nim.
Mandelbrot: See, this is why I hate you, Tripitaka.
Mandelbrot: I should have hooked up with Roger Bacon instead.
Tripitaka: He doesn't have my sense of humour though.
Mandelbrot: Fractals.
Tripitaka: I heard that.

items.title: Wednesday
items.content_text:
Mandelbrot: Listen, I really don't want to play any more.
Tripitaka: Yeah, I know. Maybe I should just tell you the secret.
Tripitaka: One last game, so I can show you?
Mandelbrot: You mean you've actually worked it out?
Mandelbrot: Finally.
Tripitaka: So I can pick one, two or three.
Tripitaka picks up a coin and taps it against his teeth.
Mandelbrot collects three coins from the pile.
Tripitaka: So I tap, tap, tap. And you pick up three coins.
Tripitaka takes two coins and strikes them together.
Mandelbrot also picks up two coins.
Tripitaka: So I go da-ding!
Tripitaka: And you take two coins.
Tripitaka takes three coins and clicks his fingers.
Mandelbrot takes a coin from the pile.
Tripitaka: So I go snap!
Tripitaka: And you take one coin.
Mandelbrot: Very funny.
Tripitaka: It's an old Taoist technique.
Mandelbrot: Really.
Tripitaka: Cavity modulation of Chi pulses, coupling into your nervous system to act as a pre-cognitive modifier.
Mandelbrot: Well that would explain all the tapping and the coughing and the farting.
Tripitaka: Maybe not the farting.
Mandelbrot: You've had me play hundreds of times.
Tripitaka: Sorry. I needed enough experiments to be statistically significant.
items.content_html:
Wednesday

  • Mandelbrot

    Listen, I really don't want to play any more.

  • Tripitaka

    Yeah, I know. Maybe I should just tell you the secret.

  • Tripitaka

    One last game, so I can show you?

  • Mandelbrot

    You mean you've actually worked it out?

  • Mandelbrot

    Finally.

  • Tripitaka

    So I can pick one , two or three .

items.title: Monday
items.content_text:
Tripitaka: Mandelbrot.
Mandelbrot: Yes?
Tripitaka: It is chilly, and there are leaves on the ground.
Mandelbrot: Yes, it is Autumn.
Tripitaka: Should we play again, do you think?
Mandelbrot: Must we?
Tripitaka: Well, it is Autumn.
Mandelbrot sighs. He takes from his purse a handful of coins, and drops them at their feet.
Mandelbrot: Well go on then. You first.
Tripitaka: Do the voice.
Mandelbrot: You may choose one, two or three coins.
Mandelbrot: But choose wisely!
Tripitaka takes a single silver piece and puts it to one side.
Mandelbrot scrapes at the ground and ends up with three.
Tripitaka takes two coins and holds them aloft.
Mandelbrot takes the same.
Tripitaka takes three coins and rattles them together.
Mandelbrot takes one coin from the pile.
Tripitaka: I'm afraid I might be a little rusty.
Mandelbrot: Take your time.
Mandelbrot: You can have either one, two or three coins.
Tripitaka drums his fingers a little. He takes one coin.
Mandelbrot carefully selects three.
Tripitaka takes two coins from the small pile.
Mandelbrot takes another two.
Tripitaka clucks with his tongue and hesitates.
Mandelbrot: Entirely up to you.
Tripitaka suddenly takes three coins.
Mandelbrot takes one coin for himself.
Tripitaka: Exciting. Not many left now.
Tripitaka has the choice of one, two or three coins.
Mandelbrot chuckles slightly.
Mandelbrot: Three, and I win.
Mandelbrot gives a little wink.
Mandelbrot: Two, and I win.
Mandelbrot shakes his head.
Mandelbrot: One, and I win.

  • Tripitaka

    Mandelbrot.

  • Mandelbrot

    Yes?

  • Tripitaka

    It is chilly, and there are leaves on the ground.

  • Mandelbrot

  • Tripitaka

    Should we play again, do you think?

  • Mandelbrot

    Must we?

  • Tripitaka

    Well, it is Autumn.

  • Mandelbrot sighs. He takes from his purse a handful of coins, and drops them at their feet.
